Title: KYY X90D Triple Portable Monitor Review: A screaming dual-screen bargain at $250
Description:
Why you can trust Tom's Hardware Our expert reviewers spend hours testing and comparing products and services so you can choose the best for you. Find out more about how we test.

It‚Äôs been a year since we looked at KYY‚Äôs X90A portable monitor, but the company is back with a new variant called the X90D. The X90D seems strikingly similar to its elder sibling, but has slightly larger display panels, each measuring 15.6 inches across.

The resolution stays the same at 1920 x 1080, and KYY includes what we loved about the original: the integrated kickstand and multiple operating modes to suit your needs. Even better, the X90D is available for well below the $400 price of the X90A we reviewed in early 2024. Does the X90D now allow KYY to strike it big on the list of the best portable monitors ? Read on to find out.

Design of the KYY X90D Triple Portable Monitor

The KYY X90D looks just like the X90A, albeit with slightly larger display panels (15.6 inches versus 14 inches). The similarities pay off regarding build quality, as this is a solid, well-built unit with a chassis made entirely of aluminum. It's also hefty, weighing 3.2 pounds, but that‚Äôs the price you must pay to lug around two 15.6-inch display panels and the accompanying hardware.

The X90D‚Äôs displays both feature a 360-degree hinge. In the Extended mode, both displays flank your laptop's built-in display. You can adjust the hinge to achieve your desired viewing angle for both. In Presentation mode, you can swing both displays backward to share your screens with people sitting across from you.

Image 1 of 3 (Image credit: Tom's Hardware) (Image credit: Tom's Hardware) (Image credit: Tom's Hardware)

There are also in-between modes, which make use of only one panel. Depending on how you position the stand and/or built-in kickstand, you can use just one display mounted horizontally or vertically.

The kickstand is also constructed of aluminum and features a stiff hinge. It can support the full weight of the X90D and is highly adjustable to achieve an ideal viewing angle with the dual displays.

According to KYY, the X90D is optimized to work with 12- to 16-inch laptops. I primarily used the X90D with a 14-inch MacBook Pro , which nestled perfectly between the twin panels. In addition, the black finish of the X90D nearly matched the Space Black of my laptop.

Image 1 of 6 (Image credit: Tom's Hardware) (Image credit: Tom's Hardware) (Image credit: Tom's Hardware) (Image credit: Tom's Hardware) (Image credit: Tom's Hardware) (Image credit: Tom's Hardware)

Each display panel has a set of controls on the bottom bezel. The right display panel features +/-, Menu, and Power buttons, while the left panel features +/- and Menu. There are also only two ports on the monitor, both USB-C.

The X90D will connect with laptops that support Thunderbolt or USB-C with DisplayPort Alt-Mode. If your laptop provides enough juice, the X90D will operate with a single USB-C cable. However, if you need auxiliary power, KYY wisely includes an additional USB-C to USB-A cable and a USB-A wall adapter in the box.

Unfortunately, unlike the Limink LK14 , the X90D doesn‚Äôt come with a case or screen protectors. This makes transporting the portable monitor, with its rotating screens just dangling loosely in space when stowed, highly susceptible to damage. I would gladly pay an extra $5 or $10 to get a decent carrying case specifically designed for the X90D in the box from the factory.

KYY X90D Triple Portable Monitor Specifications

Swipe to scroll horizontally Panel Type / Backlight IPS / WLED Screen Size / Aspect Ratio 15.6 inches / 16:9 Max Resolution & Refresh Rate 1920 x 1080 @ 60Hz x2 Max Brightness 300 nits Contrast 1,200:1 Ports 2x USB-C (DisplayPort Alt Mode) Dimensions 11.9 x 17.3 x 3.74 inches Weight 3.2 pounds

Connecting the KYY X90D Triple Portable Monitor

Given the lack of HDMI ports on the X90D, you're out of luck if your laptop lacks Thunderbolt ports or support for DisplayPort Alt-Mode over USB-C. This is disappointing for users with older laptops or anyone with a Raspberry Pi who wants to partake in some dual-screen action.

However, since my MacBook Pro has three Thunderbolt 4 ports, it was fully equipped to accommodate the X90D. Better yet, the MacBook Pro can power the X90D with a single cable, which cuts down on the cable clutter that can sometimes arise with competing dual-screen portable monitor solutions.

I'm used to just plugging in a monitor and it being instantly recognized by the operating system. That wasn't the case here. I plugged the X90D into my MacBook Pro, and it powered on. Then, it gave me "No Signal" warnings on both displays. It next showed, "Entering Low Power Mode" and then shut down. In my haste, I hadn't bothered to look at the quick start guide, which said I first needed to install a display driver for the monitor. Luckily, KYY provides a thumb drive that has both USB-A and USB-C connectors for universal support. I plugged the thumb drive in, selected the version of the driver that supports macOS Sequoia, and installed it on my system.

At that point, I plugged the X90D's USB-C cable back into the MacBook Pro and both displays fired up as expected. MacOS Sequoia defaulted to extend my desktop on the right display and mirror my laptop's internal display on the left display. After navigating to display settings and flipping a couple of switches, I had the X90D operating as an extended display on both panels, expanding my workspace on either side of my MacBook Pro's internal display.

OSD on the KYY X90D Triple Portable Monitor

Each display on the X90D has its own on-screen display (OSD) and set of controls for navigation. This can come in handy, as you can choose from five preset display modes: Standard, Game, Movie, Photo, and Vivid. If you want to devote one screen to watching a movie and one for gaming, you can dial in settings specifically to suit the needs of each.

(Image credit: Tom's Hardware)

It takes a while to become acclimated with the OSD. You first press the Menu button to bring up the OSD, then use the + or ‚Äì buttons to navigate right or left. You then press the Menu button again to go deeper into a submenu. Once you‚Äôve landed on an actionable item, you can use the +/- buttons to increase or decrease the value (i.e., brightness, contrast, black level, sharpness, etc.).

Besides the usual color and brightness settings, there are controls for the OSD time, and vertical/horizontal positioning of the OSD window. Unfortunately, KYY hasn‚Äôt fixed my main gripe with the OSD controls from the X90A. The X90D still positions the controls on the lower right corner (left display) and lower left corner (right display). That places the controls precariously close to the hinge and where your laptop meets the central spine of the X90D. It makes navigating the OSD awkward as you must angle your fingers into the narrow nook to make adjustments.

Image Quality on the KYY X90D Triple Portable Monitor

The X90D is a dual-screen IPS portable monitor, with each Full HD (1920 x 1080) display measuring 15.6 inches across. The monitor has a claimed maximum brightness of 300 nits, a contrast ratio of 1,200:1, and a 60Hz refresh rate. The display panels also have a matte finish, which helps to cut down on reflections.

According to our colorimeter testing, the X90D improved upon the X90A in color performance. In the Standard picture setting (the default mode), we measured 81.3 percent coverage of sRGB and 57.6 percent of DCI-P3. While those are appreciable gains over its predecessor, things took a step backwards regarding overall brightness.

(Image credit: Tom's Hardware)

We measured 181.4 nits maximum panel brightness for both panels on the X90D. For comparison, the X90A achieved 227.8 nits with default settings, which was already at the bottom of the class. If there's any consolation, the Game and Vivid modes boosted maximum brightness to 201.2 nits and 203.6 nits, respectively.

I noticed slightly more accurate colors, particularly in the reds and greens, compared to the disappointing performance of the elder X90A. I watched several movies with the left display while going through my daily work routine with my laptop‚Äôs internal display and the right display. The 2002 Leonardo DiCaprio flick Catch Me if You Can looked great on the monitor with its 1960‚Äôs aesthetic and bright color palette, as did the first three episodes of Marvel‚Äôs Daredevil: Born Again. My only major complaint about the monitor is regarding brightness.

With spring approaching, and daytime temperatures in the mid-70s here in the southern states, I like to spend part of the afternoon working on my back porch to get some fresh air and listen to nature. However, the displays weren‚Äôt as bright as I wanted them to be to counteract the ambient light. Of course, it‚Äôs hard to make fair comparisons when X90D is flanking the far superior (and much brighter) internal Mini-LED display on my MacBook Pro, but KYY could do better here.

Honestly, most people will likely stick to using the X90D indoors, where its brightness was more than adequate under the overhead LED lighting in my home. Whether I was watching movies, working on Word documents, or bashing around in Pixelmator Pro, the dual 1920 x 1080 displays were more than up to the task of handling those tasks.

Bottom Line

The KYY X90D is an impressive piece of kit. It has a well-built and sleek aluminum chassis, and its color performance improves upon the X90A that came before it. However, the X90D isn‚Äôt perfect ‚Äì no product is. Maximum brightness regressed, and KYY still hasn‚Äôt changed the awkward positioning of the OSD controls. In addition, KYY doesn‚Äôt provide a case in the box to protect the display panels from damage when not in use.

Title: 6 unknown browsers but better than Chrome
Description:
I no longer count the number of browsers that I have tested and used over the years. Knowing the number of web browsers available, I am always surprised that some remain in the shadows, even those which are superior to those used by the majority of Internet users.

Receive a selection of strategic advice and concrete tips every week in your mailbox with our newsletter practical guides. Learn more about the use of personal data

I think many of these alternatives are not more widespread simply because most users do not know them.

Here are five web browsers who deserve to be tested.

1 arc

I guess whoever tests the Arc navigator will definitely want to adopt it. Yes, Arc is really excellent. It took me five minutes to understand that Cart should be my default web browser on macOS, and I do not regret this choice.

What I like most about the Arc browser is its effective management of tabs thanks to a functionality called spaces. Thanks to spaces, you can create different workspaces for the associated tabs and easily switch from one to the other by sweeping to the right or the left (on your touchpad). You can also move tabs between the spaces and save them in the form of a folder.

ARC has an elegant interface and is as efficient as any browser on the market. It benefits from regular updates.

ARC is available for free on MacOS, Windows and iOS. One day, The Browser Company may plan to create a linux version of the browser.

2 hummingbird

Colibri is a browser with a refined interface, designed to be light, compact and fast. It is unique among modern browsers because it does not have tabs. You have a site by window, and that's it. Want to visit another site? Open a new Colibri window!

With Colibri, create an account on which you can record links, lists and streams. Turn between the site you currently consult and your account view to find the site you want to visit. This system maintains the minimalist and easy -to -use hummingbird user interface. Admittedly, this is far from what you are used to, but once you have taken the helping hand and discovered the refined interface, you will quickly appreciate this browser for its speed and simplicity.

Colibri is available for Linux, MacOS and Windows. You can request a free download link at the bottom of the home website home page.

3 Maxthon

Maxthon combines several impressive features in a web browser. Among these are the vocal synthesis, the IA cat, the reading mode, the integrated notebook, the pinned tabs, the extensions, the advertising blocking, the private navigation mode, a free VPN, a integrated password manager, the shared screen, the videos download, data cleaning and a customizable user interface with themes.

With the integrated AI cat, the number of free requests is limited. However, you can select the type of AI you want to use: cats for technology, writing, well-being, and an extraterrestrial for fun. The Chat IA offers two modes: fast mode offers daily free uses, and expert mode requires diamonds (an integrated purchase) and costs depending on the number of conversations.

Maxthon is based on chromium and can be installed for free on MacOS, Windows, Android and iOS.

4 Aloha

Another chromium derivative, Aloha offers a level of safety that Chrome cannot match (at least without significant modifications).

With Aloha, you benefit from a VPN, the blocking of advertisements, a locking by code or biometric, a confidentiality report, a simplified data management, third -party security audits, omnipresent HTTPS and private chat by AI. You also have the translation of pages, a reading mode, a multimedia player, a night mode, a manager of integrated files, multithreads downloads, locked folders, sharing files in Wi-Fi, profiles, themes and much more.

Aloha also offers premium access, which offers you a faster VPN (with more locations), automatic VPN connection, more customizations, advanced file management and much more. Of all alternative browsers, Aloha is the one that most resembles Chrome. If you don't want to change, it's a great option.

Aloha can be downloaded and installed for free on MacOS, Windows, Android and iOS. To find out more, see the Aloha download page.

5 freewolf

Freewolf is based on Firefox. The main difference between the two browsers lies in the fact that Freewolf mainly focuses on confidentiality, security and freedom. It was designed to protect against tracking and fingerprinting, with some additional safety improvements via fixes and parameters. Freewolf also guarantees the absence of telemetry and offers private searches via DuckDuckGo, Searx, Qwant, and many others.

Librewolf is configured to automatically delete cookies and data from the websites when closed, integrates Ublockorigin as soon as the packaging is released, deletes the tracking elements of all URLs, and much more. You will find all the information on confidentiality and security improvements made to freewolf here. Freewolf is aimed at those who appreciate the Firefox user interface but want to take web security seriously.

Freewolf can be installed free of charge on Linux, MacOS and Windows.

6 bonuses: ulaa

I recently discovered another little -known browser who, in my opinion, was to appear on this list. It is Ulaa, created by the developers of the Zoho suite. Ulaa emphasizes confidentiality, security and speed. With ULAA, you benefit from anonymized statistics, from a 24 -hour security correction policy, protection against high -risk threats, automatic updates on all platforms, automatic reset of browser identifiers, geographic insulation of data, the absence of data sent to third parties, the absence of PUSH updates of customers, reported, absence of motion sensors, lack of integration of third -party accounts, lack of network time monitoring, and much more.

Consider ULAA as a clone of chrome, much more secure. You can also use the browser in different modes: work, staff, developer, children, free access and private navigation. Ulaa is also distinguished from many chrome clones by its exceptional speed. I don't think I saw a browser display the ZDNET page so quickly. The rendering speed is greater than that of all the browsers that I have used so far.

Ulaa is compatible with Linux, MacOS, Android and iOS.

Title: My 7 favorite Android widgets to make a phone or a ...
Description:
I will start this article by specifying that the choice of widgets is personal, and that what can be useful to me is not necessarily so for you. Despite everything, there is a widget for everyone, and according to the applications installed on your Android device, you will probably find one or two in this article to help you gain in efficiency.

Receive a selection of strategic advice and concrete tips every week in your mailbox with our newsletter practical guides. Learn more about the use of personal data

Widgets are additions to your Android home screen which allows you to quickly access applications of applications, applications themselves or services on which you depend. With the right collection of widgets, you can create a quick home screen that allows you to stay informed without opening up the slightest application.

I have traveled the widgets for phones and tablets, and I share those which, in my opinion, will make your phone or tablet more useful.

Google Agenda

Show the month or the whole day

As I regularly consult my Google agenda, I find the widget very useful.

You can add a widget to display the whole month or a daily widget. From each widget, you can consult the events and even press the + button to add an event to your agenda.

Namely: if you use several calendars on Gmail, you will need to add a widget for everyone.

Gmail (or your favorite messaging application)

Add the widget to your default email application (mine is Thunderbird) allows you to have a quick overview of the content of your reception box and easily access the application writing window.

For the Thunderbird widget, press the pencil icon to automatically open the editorial window where you can write an email.

If you depend on your messaging to stay connected, this widget is essential.

3 Keep Notes

Quickly note information

I use Keep Notes daily to quickly note information, share racing lists and much more. I use some of my notes in Google Keep throughout my working day (some contain important links of links).

To quickly access these links, I added the "Notes" widget. You can add two widgets: one to scroll through your notes and one to quickly create new notes (text, voice and even images from your camera).

For this widget, I recommend adding the scrolling widget to the tablets and the quick access buttons widget on phones. I favor this option because the screen of your phone is much smaller than that of a tablet, and it is better not to clutter it with too many bulky widgets.

4 Arc Search

Navigate the internet quickly

Arc Search is a great way to do quick research on the internet. The addition of Arc Search as a widget offers functionalities similar to the Google Standard search bar, but automatically opens Arc Search instead of chrome.

If you prefer to get away from Google search, I strongly recommend that you install Arc Search and add the widget to your home screen.

5 battery

Load level information

There is already a battery indicator at the top of your phone screen. However, this indicator does not provide any information on the load level of connected devices.

I can add the battery widget to my home screen to get a quick overview of the load level of my Pixel Watch, my connected headphones, etc. The Android battery widget is an excellent tool for knowing the remaining autonomy of your devices.

6 Pixel weather

For pixel phones only

Android's "preview" feature indicates the ambient temperature and you can press it to open the weather app. However, its use is not always simple. We often hesitate to choose between the weather app and the calendar application.

To avoid any confusion, I added the Pixel weather widget. Admittedly, it is an exclusive feature at the pixel, but it is much more practical than trying to read the small characters of the "preview" option.

7 Spotify

Access your playlists

Spotify is my favorite musical application on Android and on a computer. The Spotify widget allows me to quickly access my reading lists.

Before running, I just have to press my favorite playlist and leave. Then, as soon as a music is in reading, I can control it from the widget.

How to add a widget to your Android device

This step is simple. Just press an empty space of your home screen for a long time, press "widgets", search for the widget to add to the displayed window and drag it to your home screen. You can then resize the widget and move it according to your needs.

Title: Is a VPN enough to guarantee anonymity online, or can we always ...
Description:
This is a completely legitimate question that everyone can - and even must - ask themselves before choosing a VPN. To answer it, it is essential to understand the functioning of a VPN. So here is an accelerated course on what can (or cannot) do such a tool for your online anonymity.

How does a VPN work?

The principle of a VPN is to establish a encrypted tunnel between the user's device and the Internet access provider. Normally, when accessing a website, your IP address and other personal information is broadcast online. With a VPN, this data first goes through a secure server that takes care of hiding them, strengthening anonymity. In other words, a VPN is used to protect privacy, secure a connection (especially on public Wi-Fi) and possibly bypass certain geographic restrictions.

It is still necessary that the chosen VPN is effective: encryption, confidentiality policy, reliability of the VPN connection ... Different criteria must be taken into consideration to have the assurance that your identity is well protected.

¬© Surfshark

Can a VPN guarantee total anonymity?

The short answer is as follows: yes, but with nuances ... All VPNs are not equal. Free services are often less secure and can keep connection newspapers (logs). This is why, if you are looking to be anonymous, it is best to turn to a paid service. It is also important to verify the privacy policy before taking out a subscription.

To maximize your chances of navigating anonymously, favor a VPN which:

Apply a strict policy of "no-log" (no data preservation), this is the case, for example, of surfhark;

Uses high-level encryption (AES-256) and advanced protocols (Kev2, OpenVPN and Wireguard);

Has advanced features such as "Kill Switch" and "Dynamic Multihop";

Integrates a stealth mode, capable of hiding the fact that you use a VPN.

Anyway, keep in mind that in the digital age, absolute anonymity on the Internet is almost impossible. On the other hand, preserving its confidentiality online is an achievable objective. It is indeed possible to hide your activities, protect your personal data and limit the digital traces left on the sites and applications consulted.

Can we be followed online despite a VPN?

¬© Sarshark

Your online confidentiality is threatened by many elements. If the use of a reliable VPN is effective protection, it is not enough alone. Its effectiveness is also based on the adoption of good practices and other protection tools.

Your online confidentiality threatened by your own accounts

When it comes to preserving your privacy on the Internet, one of the first elements likely to compromise your anonymity remains the use of your personal accounts, starting with those of Google or social networks. Even using a VPN to hide your IP address, connection to these services is enough to identify you and trace your activity online.

Cookies and tracers

Even if you use a VPN, cookies are always able to follow your activity online. Some VPNs offer extensions that settle on the Internet browser in order to block all the tracers and by the way, protect the user from intrusive advertisements.

Risks related to malware

Malventy (or malware) software represents another serious threat. Some are able to steal your identifiers and passwords, while others, such as spyware, monitor your activity. The Keyloggers even go so far as to record the keyboard strikes. A VPN should be coupled with an effective antivirus in order to guard against these threats.
